discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Definitely D:

"Automatically Install the Cisco Umbrella Root Certificate (For an Active Directory Network)
As a network administrator of an Active Directory network environment, you can automatically install the Cisco Umbrella root certificate in all of your users' browsers by creating a Group Policy Object (GPO) on your Active Directory server. This can be created by using either the Microsoft Management Console (MMC) or the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC)."

https://docs.umbrella.com/deployment-msp/docs/install-the-cisco-umbrella-root-certificate

choices.A: Restrict access to only websites with trusted third-party signed certificates.
choices.C: Upload the organization root CA to Cisco Umbrella.
choices.D: Install the Cisco Umbrella root CA onto the user's device.
choices.B: Modify the user's browser settings to suppress errors from Cisco Umbrella.

questions.question_text: An engineer enabled SSL decryption for Cisco Umbrella intelligent proxy and needs to ensure that traffic is inspected without alerting end-users. Which action accomplishes this goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/wsa/wsa_12-0/user_guide/b_WSA_UserGuide_12_0.pdf

comments.content:
This. Page 282:
"To allow all content security appliances in your organization to view file analysis result details in the cloud for files sent for analysis from any appliance in your organization, you need to join all appliances to the same appliance group."

discussion.content:
"All WSAs in the group can view file analysis results" is also a valid function of joining Cisco WSAs to an appliance group. When WSAs are joined to a group, they can share information and data, including file analysis results, which can help improve overall security efficacy.

However, it's worth noting that the primary purpose of joining WSAs to an appliance group is to support improved redundancy, as I mentioned earlier. So, both options A and B are correct answers, but B is the more commonly cited reason for joining WSAs to an appliance group.

comments.content: So are we saying B is the correct answer based on Cisco's incredibly ambiguous questioning format? Thanks.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The question ask about benefit of joining WSA together, that means we already have multiple WSA in place. Therefore Answer A should be correct.

Selected Answer: B
Say you've got 1 WSA that can view file analysis results, What is the purpose off adding a 2nd WSA ? It would be absurd to answer ' so i can view file analysis results ' !!!! The answer has to be redundancy.

Selected Answer: B
The purpose normal human being install something more than 1 in their network is to improved redundancy. Option A is very ridiculous answer. Its a plus point. But the primary purpose should be B. :-(
B - What is the purpose guys, are you joining multiple WSA appliances together to view file analysis or to get redundancy and high availability features.
If you search for "Appliance Group" in Cisco's manual, the only reference is under "Public Cloud File Analysis Services" - so A is the best answer.

Selected Answer: A
I would take A: Your are joining with appliance not WSA or ESA for clustering ( failover capabilities)

I would go with A. "file analysis"

You can view the File Analysis details on the Service Status page of the new web interface of your appliance. You must join all managed appliances to the same appliance group in order to allow all content security appliances in your organization to display detailed results in the cloud about files sent for analysis from any Cisco Email Security appliance or Cisco Web Security appliance in your organization

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/security_management/sma/sma14-0/b_sma_admin_guide_14_0/b_NGSMA_Admin_Guide_chapter_0111.html

choices.A: All WSAs in the group can view file analysis results.
choices.D: It simplifies the task of patching multiple appliances.
choices.C: It supports cluster operations to expedite the malware analysis process.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of joining Cisco WSAs to an appliance group?
Which technology should be used to help prevent an attacker from stealing usernames and passwords of users within an organization?

comments.content: ok, it makes sense. But if non-username/password authentication goes first, man in the middle will never got to credentials either (as well putting aside that it will be encrypted and he will see nothing anyway). So again - thank you Cisco, hope they are marking both answers if selected as correct, otherwise the exams are becoming quite shitty

discussion.content:
Within the organisation. I go for DAI. 

C

Selected Answer: C
Can't be D cause you need creds before MFA so that means your username and password already been compromised.
Answer d

comments.content: With MFA applied, your organization has a next layer of protection against illegitimate access. The attacker might steal the credentials for basic authentication with user+PW, still it won't get inside of the company infrastructure. For me it is C.

discussion.content: Look at the next question that states MFA assists with stopping Phishing. Phishing is used to gain user credentials.

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C.
MFA doesn't prevent stealing, it prevents to get a benefit from/after stealing.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Attacker can't use randomly generated password from MFA device.

Correct answer D

Selected Answer: C
B relates to OS detection
D relates to mitigating unauthorised access and you'll likely already have the correct username and password i.e. it doesn't help prevent an attacker stealing credentials.

DAI, protect against man in the middle attack.

questions.question_text: Which solution for remote workers enables protection, detection, and response on the endpoint against known and unknown threats?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It is asking about protection on the endpoint for remote workers. The other options aren't addressing protection on the endpoint.
Anyconnect is the product suite
Duo is MFA
Umbrella protects against web/dns based threats.

questions.question_text: Which two actions does the Cisco Identity Services Engine posture module provide that ensures endpoint security? (Choose two.)

choices.C: A centralized management solution is deployed.
choices.A: Assignments to endpoint groups are made dynamically, based on endpoint attributes.
choices.E: The latest antivirus updates are applied before access is allowed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Answer is D & E

Selected Answer: DE
A,B and C do not increase the security of the endpoint (though A might increase the security of the overall network).

D and E, however, do increase the endpoint's security level.

Selected Answer: DE
Only D and E can be pusture models

Selected Answer: DE
ISE posture assessment includes a set of rules in a security policy that define a series of checks before an endpoint is granted access to the network. Posture assessment checks include the installation of OS patches, host based firewall, antivirus and anti-malware software, disk encryption and more, Answer is D & E
